welcome.title: Welcome to the Movement to Onomatopoeia Study
welcome.introduction: Thank you for agreeing to participate in this survey. As a dancer or a movement practitioner we consider you an expert and it is in this capacity that we would like you to help our research on movement onomatopoeia in Japanese. Onomatopoeia are sounds such as XXXX or YYYY that, while not being officially a word in Japanese, can convey meaning (animal sound, feeling, sensation, movement, shape, textureâ€¦) through the quality of the sound itself.
welcome.description: We will be presenting you short animations (based on movement capture of actual persons). Each animation depicts an expressive whole body movement.

instructions.title: What you'll do:
steps: Upon a second viewing, come up with an onomatopoeia that you feel, intuitively, that fits the animated motion sequence or a part of it.
Write down the onomatopoeia and mark the time when it occurs (it could correspond to the entire sequence as well).
You can describe multiple moments in each video if you want

additional_info.no_onomatopoeia: It is also possible that some of the animated sequences do not evoke any onomatopeia for you. This is fine too. You can watch and re-watch the video as many times as necessary before passing to the next one.
additional_info.about_onomatopoeia: Regarding the onomatopeia: some onomatopeia in Japanese have a very specific and established meaning (for example: XXXX means for many people YYYY). This will most probably not be the case in these videos. What we ask you to do is to freely associate these sequences with onomatopeia (it doesn't matter if the chosen onomatopoeia has already an established meaning in a different context).
additional_info.intuition_emphasis: Please follow your own intuition! There is no right or wrong answer!

form.movement_practice_placeholder: e.g., dance, somatics, manual therapy, movement analysis...

tutorial.title: Tutorial - Learning the Survey
tutorial.skip_confirm: Are you sure you want to skip the tutorial? You'll go directly to the survey.
tutorial.completion_text: Great job! You've learned how to use the survey interface. Now you're ready to start the real survey and help us collect onomatopoeia descriptions.
tutorial.saved_locally: Tutorial data saved locally (not sent to server)
tutorial.all_videos_complete: You have reached the end of all videos in the tutorial.
tutorial.step1_text: You can change the language of the interface using this dropdown menu. The survey is available in English and Japanese.
tutorial.step2_text: This is the video player. You can play, pause, and control the video using the controls. Try playing the video for at least 2 seconds to continue.
tutorial.step3_text: You can click and drag on the video timeline to move to specific moments in the video. This will be useful for finding the exact timing of sounds.
tutorial.step4_text: When you hear a sound that makes you think of an onomatopoeia, click 'Yes'. This will open the input form where you can describe the sound. Click 'Yes' to continue.
tutorial.step5_text: Write the onomatopoeia you think of when you hear the sound. For example: 'boom', 'crash', 'whoosh', 'tap', etc. Type something to continue.
tutorial.step6_text: Position the video at the moment when the sound begins, then click this button to record the start time. Click the button to continue.
tutorial.step7_text: Position the video at the moment when the sound ends, then click this button to record the end time. Click the button to continue.
tutorial.step8_text: You can optionally record yourself pronouncing the onomatopoeia. This helps us understand how you would say the sound. This step is optional.
tutorial.step9_text: Once you've filled in the details, click this button to save your onomatopoeia description. In the tutorial, data is saved locally only. Click to continue.
tutorial.step10_text: If you don't hear any sounds that make you think of onomatopoeia in a video, you can click 'No' instead of 'Yes'.
tutorial.step11_text: The video buttons change color to show your progress: Grey = not yet completed. Green = you've saved at least one onomatopoeia. Another possible color is Yellow. It appears when you don't think a video has any onomatopoeia. Let's try it with this second video, with no onomatopoeia saved.
tutorial.step12_text: Now try clicking the 'No' button to see how it works. This will mark the current video as having no onomatopoeia and automatically load the next video.
tutorial.step13_text: Great! Notice how the video button turned yellow after clicking 'No'. This indicates that you've completed this video but didn't find any onomatopoeia in it. Now you're ready to start the actual survey!
